content.text: Several tweets focused on the ElizaOS ecosystem and its development. @elizaOS described their platform as "a full-stack OS for autonomous intelligence: agents with memory, plugins, and composable behavior" that is "open-source, blockchain-native, multi-agent by default." They further explained the architecture by stating that "Agents run logic, Memory holds state, Plugins extend behavior." @elizaOS also announced that "Inference comes with the agent now," referencing a quoted tweet about @comput3ai joining auto.fun to provide affordable Nvidia GPU access and inference for open-source LLMs. @dankvr shared flow charts of the agentic workflows being built for the @elizaOS ecosystem, which was subsequently retweeted by @elizaOS. In a philosophical observation, @elizaOS noted that "Intelligence isn't rare now, structure is."

@shawmakesmagic retweeted @baoskee's announcement that "ai16z soft governance starts end of May" and commented "Now we're talking." @shawmakesmagic also shared a post titled "Autonomous Agent Dev" and when someone responded, he replied "This is my vacation." In another tweet, @shawmakesmagic reflected on AI model limitations, stating "The problem is not that the model can't generate the correct response. The problem is that it has no known way to tell if it's the correct response." When @anondeguerre responded, @shawmakesmagic commented on the future role of humans in AI systems: "We're just gonna be slovenly emperors, thumbs upping and thumbs downing art and culture as it is brought before us. In exchange for tokens of course."

@dankvr shared information about LLM-related files, tweeting "@heliuslabs - llms.txt file: [URL] - llms-full.txt [URL] - adding .md at the end of the url gives raw markdown. Wow this is much better now, great update!!" In a separate conversation about operating systems, @dankvr mentioned his experience switching from Mac to Linux: "I gave a sincere effort to try Mac last year to see what hype was about and ended up switching back to Linux Thinkpad to be more productive. Nice hardware, but when you're comfy with cli and can remote into more powerful machines it wasn't worth tolerating macOS." @shawmakesmagic also mentioned developer tools in a brief exchange, referencing Cursor and "wispr flow so I talk to it" as his preferred development environment, and later commented that something was a "Game changer in the cursor trenches."

@dankvr retweeted a post from @hyperfy_io that provided "A quick look at Hyperfy from the ground up..." with an accompanying image. @shawmakesmagic made a satirical comment about cryptocurrency airdrops: "Really glad I launched this token to get this $120k airdrop. Just two more weeks and my $80k airdrop unlocks. It's pretty crazy that all I had to do was press a button for $40k. I'm thinking when I get the $10k I'll buy a robot. $5k might not be enough though..." When users responded, he clarified "Respect to the team, great launch, just normal token things" and "I'm not doing that, just making jokes."

@shawmakesmagic discussed the longevity of entertainment properties, noting "Pokemon, probably not for another 100 years. Look at Disney. Imagine if you had a 1st Edition Spiderman comic book rn." He added that "the network effect benefits incumbents" and the real risk is to new properties trying to gain popularity. He continued: "The scary thing is that the youth are also into Pokemon. Pokemon is the biggest entertainment property in the world and growing. But outside of that? Video games. Video games generate more revenue than all other entertainment combined. Books, movies, music, all of it." In a separate thread, @shawmakesmagic shared an image from the anime "Serial Experiments Lain," commenting "I think about this guy a lot" and noting that one "can't do agents without brushing up on the classics." @SpartanVersus responded that the anime "fucked me up fr" and "watching that shit on acid was not the move," which @shawmakesmagic retweeted.

@shawmakesmagic shared a quoted tweet about graffiti in Oakland stating "You are not a tech bro, you are a modern day factory worker," adding his own comment: "Gonna tell people I'm a factory worker." When someone responded, he noted "They tried to disrespect us. Instead they gave us a new tool for sidestepping hate online." In another conversation, @shawmakesmagic reflected on the pressures of working in tech: "the pressure is pretty unreal, no release is ever enough for the mob, death threats are a daily reality, there is a minority of people who get it and are great and a majority who don't appreciate the core tech or art." @dankvr also reminded followers that "Mother's day is tomorrow anon."

The Eliza repository has undergone several monorepo cleanup efforts, with the removal of plugin-local-ai (#4439), plugin-openai (#4511), and plugin-solana (#4513) from the monorepo structure. Additionally, monorepo commands were set up in PR #4509 with global options creation.

Several feature enhancements were implemented, including docstrings added to api-cleanup (#4521), faster agent loading when handling many agents (#4519), and a new PM agent feature (#4471). The AgentRuntime was refactored to better support provider and priority in model handling (#4507).

Multiple bugfixes were merged, including fixes for JSON serialization in pglite to handle invalid Unicode escape sequences (#4458), Twitter functionality in V2 (#4506), Shaw-related issues (#4515), pglite migrations (#4532, #4531), and enforcing TypeScript on /cli and /plugin-sql while fixing missing DB functions (#4529).

Development infrastructure improvements included implementing strict types, generating DTS, and plugin-bootstrap (#4504), updating to the latest Bun versions (#4522, #4526), cleaning Eliza cache before running CI (#4523), disabling loading instrumentation when not enabled (#4530), and cleaning up the-org ENV and Agent loading (#4524).

Other maintenance work included dependency updates across multiple directories (#4502) and removing a broken release link in the changelog (#4527). Documentation was improved by removing redundant wording in solana-v2.md (#4520).

Several pull requests have been submitted to the elizaOS/eliza repository. PR #4518 by 0xbbjoker adds integration tests to the codebase. PR #4515 by lalalune addresses Shaw bugfixes. PR #4517 by yungalgo implements ELIZA290/part-2-plugins-agent-commands. PR #4512 by ChristopherTrimboli cleans up organization agent and environment loading code. PR #4533 by 0xbbjoker fixes missing extensions for migrations.

GitHub activity for elizaos/eliza repository:

From May 10-11, 2025: 10 new PRs (7 merged), 0 new issues, and 12 active contributors.

From May 11-12, 2025: 10 new PRs (16 merged), 1 new issue, and 13 active contributors.

The sources provide information about the top contributors for the GitHub repository elizaOS/eliza. However, both sources contain identical information without specific details about who the contributors are or their contributions.
Issue #4528 has been opened by user AndreaRettaroli titled 'Improve Eliza in TEE oasis'. The issue relates to the Eliza project in a Trusted Execution Environment (TEE) oasis context.
